overview: From 2025-12-21 to 2025-12-22, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 1 new PRs (2 merged), 1 new issues, and 9 active contributors.

topIssues.title: op-supernode: Ensure superroot_atTimestamp responses are consistent
topIssues.author: ajsutton
topIssues.body: As per https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/18652#discussion_r2636340003 there's a bunch of ways the `superroot_atTimestamp` response could wind up being inconsistent due to race conditions. We need to review if any of them are a concern now or are at high risk of breaking in future changes.

topPRs.title: op-challenger: PoC for super node trace provider
topPRs.author: ajsutton
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Quick PoC to check compatibility of the super node superRootAtTimestamp response with op-challenger.  Needed to tweak a couple of things but it hangs together ok.

Not trying to be clever with code reuse and haven't even integrated it with challenger yet. Just de-risking to see if the required data is actually available.

**Metadata**

Part of #18524

topPRs.title: op-challenger: Implement supernode super root provider.
topPRs.author: ajsutton
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Not currently integrated but has unit tests passing. Updated from #18617 to also handle #18643 correctly.

Adds the list of chain IDs in the dependency set at the requested timestamp to the `superroot_atTimestamp` response. The challenger could get this from the dependency set itself but it seems worth including to make the API response "stand alone" - it returns the available optimistic blocks but without the full list of chain IDs you can't tell which ones are missing without external information.

**Tests**

Implemented unit tests.

**Additional context**

Builds on #18652 

**Metadata**

#18524

topPRs.title: op-supernode: Update superroot_atTimestamp response format
topPRs.author: ajsutton
topPRs.body:
**Description**

* Stop converting all errors into not found errors.
  *  Switch to using `ethereum.NotFound` as the not found error type since we often use it as an important flag. Make it clear it must be returned in method comments.
* Move the response type to the op-service eth package so it can be reused by clients
* Remove unnecessary details
* Return partial information when a requested block is not found on one chain. The `CurrentL1` and available optimistic blocks are still returned. This allows the challenger to perform in-sync checks even if the super root is not found and to determine which intermediate step it should switch to invalid transition claims on if some but not all chains have an optimistic block.
 
**Tests**

Updated unit tests.


**Metadata**

#18524

topPRs.title: fix(verify): derive constructor args by stripping init code prefix from tx input
topPRs.author: radik878
topPRs.body: Replace the slot-counting approach for constructor argument extraction with a robust method that strips the artifact init bytecode prefix from the deployment transaction input, ensuring correctness for dynamic and nested types per Solidity ABI. The prior implementation incorrectly approximated dynamic data sizes (e.g., treating strings as three fixed slots) and could both miscompute arguments and panic on invalid slices. The new logic uses the Foundry artifactâ€™s Bytecode.Object as the canonical init code, validates that the transaction input starts with this prefix, and returns the remaining suffix as constructor arguments; an optional ABI decode sanity check is included to detect mismatches between artifacts and on-chain data. This aligns extraction with actual ABI encoding and removes assumptions that fail on dynamic encodings.

topPRs.title: fix(op-node): fix channel size calculation bug when pruning frames
topPRs.author: lukema95
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Fixes a bug in `Channel.AddFrame()` where the channel size was incorrectly decremented for all frames during pruning, instead of only for the frames that were actually deleted.

When a closing frame is received with a frame number lower than previously seen frames (which can happen in non-strict ordering mode), the code prunes frames with numbers >= `endFrameNumber`. However, the size calculation was subtracting the size of **all** frames in the channel, not just the ones being deleted.

**Tests**

- All existing tests pass
- New test case verifies correct behavior when pruning multiple frames
**Additional context**

**Metadata**

Include a link to any github issues that this may close in the following form:
- Fixes #[Link to Issue]
-->

topContributors.summary: ajsutton: Created a new issue (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18667) to address a supernode consistency concern, and contributed to bugfix and other work across 33 files (+1809/-185 lines) in 11 commits, while also providing 3 review comments.
Ocheretovich: Focused on enhancing the robustness of the op-node by opening a pull request, ethereum-optimism/optimism#18666, to return an error instead of panicking when the L1 chain ID is nil.
